entries.content: Be the slowest speaker in the room to convey confidence and control.
Pause frequently when speaking to create space and emphasize points.
Adopt an 'interested not interesting' approach: focus on the other person.
Lean back physically to appear relaxed and in control during conversations.
Listen intently and speak less than the prospect.
Use downward vocal inflection to convey certainty when making statements.
Avoid upward inflection at the end of sentences, which sounds like a question.
Structure communication to make declarative statements using downward inflection.
Confidence is conveyed through deliberate slowness, pausing, and vocal control.
Consciously manage your pace of speech to be slower and more deliberate.
Projecting confidence isn't about being loud or fast, but controlled and calm.
